It's difficult to say for certain, but I believe that Shakespeare's themes may have been different if he had set "Romeo and Juliet" in a different location. The setting of Verona plays an important role in shaping the cultural and historical context of the play, which in turn influences the characters and their actions. 

For example, the feudal system of Verona creates a hierarchical social structure in which the Montagues and Capulets are fierce rivals, and marriage between the two families is unthinkable. This social and historical context emphasizes the theme of feuding and rivalry, which is central to the play.

If Shakespeare had set the play in a different location with a different cultural and historical context, he may have had to adjust the themes of the play accordingly. For example, if he had set the play in a more egalitarian society, or a society with different cultural norms around love and marriage, the themes of forbidden love and familial conflict may not have been as prominent.

That being said, Shakespeare was a masterful playwright who was able to create powerful and universal themes that have resonated with audiences throughout the centuries. It's possible that even if he had set the play in a different location, he still would have been able to draw on universal experiences and emotions to create a timeless masterpiece.
